page.title: 09Sheep Shearing, Kinbrace
page.content: Sheep shearing starts in late June. Shepherds gather the sheep and take them into the sheep sheds to make sure the wool does not get wet. The shearer clips the sheep and another person rolls the fleece on a table. The fleece is taken to a bag.This bag is hung from the roof. The sheep are then dipped and marked. The children help in most of the work. The work never stops from early morning to late at night except for lunch and a tea break. The sheep manager's wife provides the food and the local women help. The children are very dirty and tired by the end of the day but are pleased with the money they have earned.Most of the shearers come from New Zealand and go to work in the different estates. The wool is collected by the Wool Marketing Board in Evanton.
